snippet: A Danish study of almost 3,000 H.I.V. patients also found that the risk of early death from cancer or heart disease was much higher among infected smokers than among noninfected ones.
abstract: Danish study published in journal Clinical Infectious Diseases finds that HIV patients who are receiving good antiretroviral treatment, but smoke, are more likely to lose years of their life to tobacco than to the virus.
lead_paragraph: A Danish study of almost 3,000 H.I.V. patients also found that the risk of early death from cancer or heart disease was much higher among infected smokers than among noninfected ones.

headline.seo: Smoking Cuts H.I.V. Patients’ Lives More Than Virus, Study Says
headline.main: Mortality: H.I.V.-Positive Smokers Lose More Years to Tobacco Than to the Virus, a Study Says
headline.print_headline: H.I.V.-Positive Smokers Lose More Years To Tobacco Than to the Virus, a Study Says
